docs.abstract: A wholesale distributor says these companies do not drive demand.
docs.snippet: A wholesale distributor says these companies do not drive demand.

headline.main: Don’t Blame Distributors for the Opioid Crisis

docs.abstract: Civil suits filed by three states accuse pharmaceutical distributors of flooding the country with opioids while devising systems to evade regulators.
docs.snippet: Civil suits filed by three states accuse pharmaceutical distributors of flooding the country with opioids while devising systems to evade regulators.
docs.lead_paragraph: There are the Sacklers, the family that controls Purdue Pharma, the maker of OxyContin. There are the doctors who ran pill mills, and the rogue pharmacists who churned out opioid orders by the thousands.

headline.main: The Giants at the Heart of the Opioid Crisis
headline.print_headline: Invisible Player In Opioid Crisis: The Distributor

byline.original: By Danny Hakim, William K. Rashbaum and Roni Caryn Rabin

docs.abstract: The companies, including Johnson & Johnson and McKesson Corporation, received subpoenas from Brooklyn prosecutors.
docs.snippet: The companies, including Johnson & Johnson and McKesson Corporation, received subpoenas from Brooklyn prosecutors.
docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn have opened a criminal investigation into whether several large drug companies intentionally skirted regulations in order to promote the sale of addictive opioids, according to corporate filings and a person familiar with the matter.

headline.main: 6 Drug Companies’ Role in Opioid Epidemic Scrutinized by Prosecutors
headline.print_headline: Drug Makers Face Inquiry Over Role In Epidemic

docs.abstract: Expectations of a whopping payday set off thousands of lawsuits. But lawyers for the suing cities and states now concede that companies will shell out far less.
docs.snippet: Expectations of a whopping payday set off thousands of lawsuits. But lawyers for the suing cities and states now concede that companies will shell out far less.
docs.lead_paragraph: As talks escalate to settle thousands of opioid-related lawsuits nationwide, a harsh reality is emerging: The money the pharmaceutical industry will pay to compensate ravaged communities will likely be far less than once envisioned.

headline.main: Payout From a National Opioids Settlement Won’t Be as Big as Hoped
headline.print_headline: Opioid Payout Won’t Be Nearly Enough to Heal All the Wounds

docs.abstract: Amazon has transformed the way Americans buy products as different as books and diapers, but with drugs, it will need to work with powerful entrenched players.
docs.snippet: Amazon has transformed the way Americans buy products as different as books and diapers, but with drugs, it will need to work with powerful entrenched players.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Amazon announced last week that it was buying the online pharmacy PillPack, it sent stocks of drugstore companies like Walgreens and Rite Aid tumbling, as investors worried that the retail behemoth would soon upend the pharmacy market.

headline.main: Why Amazon’s Push Into Prescription Drugs Isn’t a Guaranteed Success
headline.print_headline: Question for Amazon: Will Pharmacy Industry See It as Partner or Rival?

byline.original: By Katie Thomas and Claire Ballentine

docs.abstract: The state’s lawsuit offers detail on methods allegedly used to flood the market with opioids, fueling an epidemic.
docs.snippet: The state’s lawsuit offers detail on methods allegedly used to flood the market with opioids, fueling an epidemic.
docs.lead_paragraph: As investigators closed in on Purdue Pharma, the maker of the opioid painkiller OxyContin, more than a decade ago, members of the family that owns the company began shifting hundreds of millions of dollars from the business to themselves through offshore entities, the state of New York alleged in a lawsuit on Thursday.

headline.main: New York Sues Sackler Family Members and Drug Distributors
headline.print_headline: Opioid Barons Stashed Assets, N.Y. Suit Says

docs.abstract: The nation’s three largest drug distributors, as well as two manufacturers, are in intense negotiations to settle thousands of cases before a trial set to begin on Monday.
docs.snippet: The nation’s three largest drug distributors, as well as two manufacturers, are in intense negotiations to settle thousands of cases before a trial set to begin on Monday.
docs.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The nation’s three largest drug distributors and two manufacturers have agreed with multiple states on a framework to resolve thousands of opioid cases with a settlement worth nearly $50 billion in cash and addiction treatments, according to three people familiar with the negotiations.

headline.main: Drug Giants Close In on a $50 Billion Settlement of Opioid Cases
headline.print_headline: Drug Giants Nearing Settlement  Of Opioid Cases for $50 Billion

docs.abstract: The big drug distributors would pay $19.2 billion over 18 years. Some 30 states have signed on so far but most cities and counties hate the deal.
docs.snippet: The big drug distributors would pay $19.2 billion over 18 years. Some 30 states have signed on so far but most cities and counties hate the deal.
docs.lead_paragraph: The three giant drug distributors are negotiating a deal with the states to end thousands of opioid lawsuits nationwide, in which they would pay $19.2 billion over 18 years and immediately submit to stringent monitoring requirements to assure that suspicious orders for prescription opioids would be halted.

headline.main: Opioid Settlement Offer Provokes Clash Between States and Cities
headline.print_headline: Opioid Settlement Offer Leaves States and Cities at Odds

docs.abstract: The deal involves large pharmaceutical distributors and Teva, resolving cases that sought redress from the devastation caused by two decades of opioid abuse.
docs.snippet: The deal involves large pharmaceutical distributors and Teva, resolving cases that sought redress from the devastation caused by two decades of opioid abuse.
docs.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The three major drug distributors and an opioid manufacturer have reached a $260 million settlement with two Ohio counties to avoid the landmark first federal opioid trial that was set to begin here Monday.

headline.main: $260 Million Opioid Settlement Reached at Last Minute With Big Drug Companies
headline.print_headline: Settlement Is Reached as an Opioids Trial Was Set to Begin in Ohio

docs.abstract: A federal judge had summoned chief executives of drug companies and representatives of states and local governments to try to hammer out a deal. But some issues remain unresolved.
docs.snippet: A federal judge had summoned chief executives of drug companies and representatives of states and local governments to try to hammer out a deal. But some issues remain unresolved.
docs.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — After a long day of negotiations on Friday between major drug industry corporations and thousands of local governments and states suing over the companies’ role in the opioid epidemic, talks ended with the parties — even among the plaintiffs — still far apart.

headline.main: Opioid Settlement Talks Stumble With Trial Set for Monday
headline.print_headline: Opioid Settlement Talks Teeter as Trial Looms
